section.title: Kinetic Energy of a Rigid Body

introduction.p:
Kinetic energy of a particle of mass moving with speed v is given by
K = \frac{1}{2}mv^2.
Now, if we have a collection of particles m_1, m_2, \cdots, with speeds v_1, v_2, \cdots, the total kinetic energy will be just the sum.
K_\text{tot} = \frac{1}{2}\sum_{i}m_i v_i^2.
Similar to how the total angular momentum separated into angular momentum of CM and angular momentum about the CM, analogous calculations lead to the separation of total kinetic energy can be separated into a translational motion of the CM and a rotation about an axis through the CM. This rotation energy is called rotational kinetic energy.
K_\text{tot} = K_\text{cm} + K_\text{rot}
In the following section we will show that K_\text{rot} is given by
K_\text{rot} = \frac{1}{2}\,\vec\omega \cdot \vec L.
This simplifies when we work with principal axes. Then, we can write this as
K_\text{rot} = \frac{1}{2} I_{xx}\omega_x^2 + \frac{1}{2} I_{yy}\omega_y^2 + \frac{1}{2} I_{zz}\omega_z^2.
Using L_i = I_{ii}\omega_i applicable for principal axes, we can write it using angular momentum as well.
K_\text{rot} = \frac{1}{2} \frac{L_x^2}{I_{xx}} + \frac{1}{2} \frac{L_y^2}{I_{yy}} + \frac{1}{2} \frac{L_z^2}{I_{zz}}.

subsection.title: Kinetic Energy About Center of Mass
subsection.p:
We found in our last chapter that we can separate translational motion of the center of mass motion and motion about the center of mass by replacing velocity \vec v_i by sum of velocity \vec v'_i with respect to CM and velocity V_\text{cm} of the CM.
\vec v_i = \vec V_\text{cm} + \vec v'_i.
The calculation of separation gives
K_\text{tot} \amp = \frac{1}{2}\sum_{i}m_i v_i^2 = \frac{1}{2}\sum_{i}m_i \vec v_i \cdot \vec v_i \amp = \frac{1}{2}\sum_{i}m_i (\vec V_\text{cm} + \vec v'_i) \cdot (\vec V_\text{cm} + \vec v'_i) \amp = \frac{1}{2}\vec V_\text{cm} \cdot \vec V_\text{cm} \sum_{i}m_i + \vec V_\text{cm}\cdot \sum_{i}m_i \vec v'_i + \frac{1}{2}\sum_{i}m_i\vec v'_i\cdot \vec v'_i \amp = \frac{1}{2} M V_\text{cm}^2 + \frac{1}{2}\sum_{i}m_i\vec v'_i\cdot \vec v'_i.
In the last step I used the fact that \sum_{i}m_i \vec v'_i=0 since \vec v'_i are velocities with respect to the CM and have replaced total mass by M. The first part is kinetic energy of translation of the CM and the second part is the rotational kinetic energy.
\amp K_\text{cm} = \frac{1}{2} M V_\text{cm}^2. \amp K_\text{rot} = \frac{1}{2}\sum_{i}m_i\vec v'_i\cdot \vec v'_i.
By making use of the relation, \vec v' = \vec\omega \times \vec r', for each particle, we can write K_\text{rot} in terms of angular velocity and angular moementum. Thus,
K_\text{rot} \amp = \frac{1}{2}\sum_{i}m_i\vec v'_i\cdot \vec v'_i \amp = \frac{1}{2}\sum_{i}m_i(\vec\omega \times \vec r'_i)\cdot (\vec\omega \times \vec r'_i) \amp = \frac{1}{2}\sum_{i}m_i\vec\omega \cdot [ \vec r'_i \times (\vec\omega \times \vec r'_i)] \amp = \frac{1}{2}\vec\omega \cdot \sum_{i}m_i [ \vec r'_i \times (\vec\omega \times \vec r'_i)] .
The expression \sum_{i}m_i [ \vec r'_i \times (\vec\omega \times \vec r'_i)] is angular momentum \vec L about CM by . Therefore,
K_\text{rot} = \frac{1}{2}\,\vec\omega \cdot \vec L.
We can replace \vec L by {\bf I}\vec \omega, where {\bf I} is full moment of inertia, giving us
K_\text{rot} = \frac{1}{2}\,\vec\omega \cdot ( {\bf I}\vec \omega ).
We know that {\bf I} simplifies when we use principal axes of the rotating body. Therefore, in a coordinate system along principal axes we can write kinetic energy in terms of components of angular velocity as
K_\text{rot} = \frac{1}{2} I_{xx}\omega_x^2 + \frac{1}{2} I_{yy}\omega_y^2 + \frac{1}{2} I_{zz}\omega_z^2.
Often, it is useful to think of this relation in terms of angular momentum components rather than angular velocity components. Since in principal axes, L_{i} = I_{ii}\omega_i for i=x,y,z, rotational kinetic energy can also be written as
K_\text{rot} = \frac{1}{2} \frac{L_x^2}{I_{xx}} + \frac{1}{2} \frac{L_y^2}{I_{yy}} + \frac{1}{2} \frac{L_z^2}{I_{zz}}.
From this expression of K_\text{rot}, we can see that the principal axis about which moment of inertia is largest would tend to minimize kinetic energy. This leads to more stability for rotations around principal axis of largest I. If you start a rotation around an axis that has smallest moment of inertia, then, over time, the body will wobble and tend to settle in rotation about axis of largest moment of inertia.

sidebyside.p: That is why rotation of a thin disk about axis perpendicular to the disk is more stable than one about an axis in the plane of the disk.

example.title: Kinetic Energy of Rotation of a Rod

sidebyside.p: A rod of mass M and length l is poivoted at one end as shown in . At a particular instant angular speed is \omega. Find kinetic energy of the rod in two ways: (a) rotation about P, (b) sum of translation of CM and rotation about the CM.

solution.p:
(a) For rotation about P, we need moment of inertia about P, which is I=\frac{1}{3}Ml^2. Therefore, kinetic energy will be
K = \frac{1}{2}I \omega^2 = \frac{1}{6}Ml^2 \omega^2.

(b) Now, we have I_0 = \frac{1}{12}Ml^2. We also need the speed of CM. Since CM is moving in a circle of radius \frac{l}{2} with angular speed \omega, we get
V_\text{cm} = \frac{l}{2}\,\omega.
Therefore, kinetic energy will be sum of CM translational energy and rotation about the CM.
K \amp = \frac{1}{2}M V_\text{cm}^2 + \frac{1}{2}I_0 \omega^2 \amp = \frac{1}{2}M \frac{l^2}{4}\,\omega^2 + \frac{1}{2} \frac{1}{12}Ml^2 \omega^2 \amp = Ml^2 \omega^2\left( \frac{1}{8} + \frac{1}{24} \right) = \frac{1}{6}Ml^2 \omega^2.

example.title: Kinetic Energy of a Rolling Cylinder

sidebyside.p: A cylinder of mass M and radius R is rolling without slipping with center moving at speed V. What is its kinetic energy?

Kinetic energy will be sum of translational kinetic energy of center of mass and rotation about an axis through the center of mass. To find the rotation velocity, we attach a moving coordinate system in the body with origin at the center of mass as shown in .

solution.p:
From the figure, it is easy to tell that angular speed \omega will be related to speed V with which the cylider rolls on the surface.
\omega = \frac{\Delta \theta}{\Delta t} = \frac{1}{R}V.
Hence, kinetic energy will be
K \amp = \frac{1}{2}MV^2 + \frac{1}{2} I_0 \omega^2 \amp = \frac{1}{2}MV^2 + \frac{1}{2} \frac{1}{2}MR^2\omega^2 = \frac{3}{4}MV^2.

exercise.title: Kinetic Energy of a Rolling Cylinder on a Cylindrical Surface

sidebyside.p: A cylinder of mass M and radius a is rolling without slipping with center moving at speed V on a cylindrical surface of radius of curvature R as shown in . (a) What is its kinetic energy? (b) What is angular momentum about center of the center of the cylindrical surface?

hint.p: For angular velocity, think of rotation about instantaneously at-rest line as axis of rotation.

answer.p: (a) \frac{3}{4}MV^2, (b) MV\left( R - \frac{a}{2}\right) coming out of page.

solution.title: a
solution.p: Kinetic energy with respect to the fixed axis will be sum of translational kinetic energy of center of mass and rotation about an axis through the center of mass.

sidebyside.p: To find angular velocity \omega in terms of speed of CM V, we use instantaneous axis of rotation passing through point P in .

solution.p:
With velocity V of the CM about instantaneously at-rest point P at a distance a from P, angular velocity will be
\omega = \frac{V}{a}.
Therefore, kinetic energy of the cylinder will be
K \amp = \frac{1}{2}MV^2 + \frac{1}{2} I_0 \omega^2 \amp = \frac{1}{2}MV^2 + \frac{1}{2} \frac{1}{2}Ma^2\omega^2 = \frac{3}{4}MV^2.

solution.title: b
solution.p:
Both the angular momentum associated with the motion of the CM and the angular momentum about an axis through CM will be coming out of the page in . Let that axis be z-axis of body-fixed coordinate system and z' of the fixed coordinate system. Then, angular momentum about O' will be
\vec L = MV(R-a)\hat k + I_{zz}\omega\hat k.
With I_{zz} = \frac{1}{2}Ma^2 and \omega=V/a, this simlifies to
L_z = MV(R-a) + \frac{1}{2}MaV = MV\left( R - \frac{a}{2}\right).

statement.p: A cylinder of mass M, radius R and height H has a tiny hole through the center. When a pin is inserted in the hole, cylinder can rotate about the pin freely as shown in .

sidebyside.p: Holding the pin at one end, the cylinder is rolled on a flat surface such that cylinder rolls without sliding with its center moving at speed V. Find kinetic energy of the cylinder.
For the sake of simplification, let us pick a moment shown in where the principal axis Oz is in the direction of fixed axis O'x'.

solution.p:
By looking at motion of CM at x'=\frac{L}{2},\ y'=0,\ z'=R about instantaneous axis or rotation O'A, we see that angular velocity pointed towards negative z-axis with magnitude
\omega = V/R.
Therefore, we have kinetic energy
K \amp = \frac{1}{2}MV^2 + \frac{1}{2} I_{zz} \omega^2 \amp = \frac{1}{2}MV^2 + \frac{1}{2} \frac{1}{2}MR^2 (V/R)^2 = \frac{3}{4}MV^2.

exercise.title: Kinetic Energy of a Cone Rolling on Side

statement.p: A cone of mass M, height h and apex angle 2\alpha is placed on a flat surface and rolled wwithout slipping around its apex. The line touching a flat plane sweeps out \Omega rad/sec about the vertical axis as shown in . Find kinetic energy of the cone.
Center of mass of a cone is at \frac{3}{4}h from the apex and formulae for principal moments of inertia are I_1=I_2=\frac{3}{20}M\left(R^2 + \frac{1}{4}h^2 \right), I_3=\frac{3}{10}MR^2.

hint.p: Find the radius of the circle in which CM moves around O'A to get angular speed.

solution.p: shows fixed and moving coordinates. At the instant depicted in the figure, instantaneous axis of rotation is in the direction of O'A in O'x'y' plane. The origin of the moving coordinate system is at the center of mass with \overline{O'O}=\frac{3}{4}h.

sidebyside.p:
The CM will go around axis O'A in a circle of radius b given by
b = a\,\sin\alpha.
Angular speed of rotation about O'A will be
\omega = \frac{V}{b} = \frac{V}{a\,\sin\alpha}.

solution.p: Now, we work out components of angular velocity vector with respect to principal axes attached to moving cone so that we can use diagonal {\bf I}.

sidebyside.p:
Since direction of angular velocity vector is in O'A direction, the components of \vec \omega in the moving coordinate system will be
\omega_x = -\omega\,\sin\alpha , \omega_y = 0, \omega_z = \omega\,\cos\alpha.

solution.p:
Therefore, kinetic energy about O' will be
K \amp = \frac{1}{2} MV^2 + \frac{1}{2} I_{xx}\omega_x^2 + \frac{1}{2} I_{zz}\omega_z^2 \amp = \frac{1}{2} MV^2 + \frac{1}{2}\times \frac{3}{20}M\left(R^2 + \frac{1}{4}h^2 \right) \omega^2\sin^2\alpha \amp \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ + \frac{1}{2}\times \frac{3}{10}MR^2 \omega^2\,\cos^2\alpha

sidebyside.p:
We can express kinetic energy in \Omega by working out V of the CM in terms of \Omega. As showin in , CM moves in a circle of radius a\cos\alpha. Therefore,
V = \Omega a\cos\alpha.

solution.p:
Using V in \omega we get
\omega = \frac{V}{a\sin\alpha} = \frac{\Omega a\cos\alpha}{a\sin\alpha} = \Omega\,\cot\alpha.
Use these along with R = h\tan\alpha and a = 3h/4 to convert Eq. to
K = \frac{3}{40}\,Mh^2\Omega^2\left( 1 + 5 \cos^2 \alpha \right).
